thread.title: Duke duo destined, determined to dominate on the course
thread.title_full: Duke duo destined, determined to dominate on the course

title: Duke duo destined, determined to dominate on the course
text:
Duke duo destined, determined to dominate on the course 
Posted 10:25 p.m. yesterday Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters More on this 05/27: WGOLF: Duke's Maguire wins ANNIKA Award for National Player of the Year 
Durham, N.C. — Heading in to her sophomore season at Duke, Leona Maguire has a tough act to follow -- her own. 
Maguire is the returning national player of the year in women’s golf . She broke the Duke record for lowest average score, and this summer, Maguire moved up to first in the world rankings. She’s the top-ranked amateur player in the world. 
“It’s always nice to see yourself up there in rankings," Maguire said. "You know you’re definitely going in the right direction, and you’re where you need to be.” 
But as good as the sophomore from Ireland has been on the course, she’s often hard to spot. That's because Leona’s twin sister, Lisa, also plays for Duke. 
“We’re always tying to beat each other," Leona said. "I guess from a very young age we’ve always had that little bit of competitive streak in us.” 
“We push each other, we want each other to do better," said Lisa. "It just constantly helps us to improve.” 
You might say the Maguire sisters were destined for big things in golf. At the age of 10, Leona and Lisa were picked out of all the kids in Ireland to bring the Ryder Cup to the presentation stage when the Cup was held in Dublin in 2006. 
“It was the first time a big, big championship like that had been held in Ireland," Leona said. "We were just excited to be getting to go to the Ryder Cup.” 
“It kind of hit home when Tiger (Woods) walked into the tent," Lisa said. "We were just kind of awestruck and just kind of going over to him to get a picture taken.” 
“To get to bring up one of the biggest trophies in golf on a stage like that, it was pretty cool,” Leona said. 
Now, they’re winning their own trophies at Duke. Credits
